Adapt tools and utensils: Use tools designed for one-handed use, such as utensils with larger grips or handles, or utensils with a built-in lever for opening packages.

Use the other hand to help: When performing tasks that require the use of the dominant hand, such as tying shoes or buttoning clothes, use the non-dominant hand to hold the item or to assist in the process.
Develop muscle memory: Gradually develop muscle memory for tasks that typically require the dominant hand. This can include brushing teeth, using a phone, or opening packages.
Seek assistance: Don't hesitate to ask for help from others when needed. Friends, family, or even strangers can offer assistance with tasks that are difficult to perform with one hand.

Practice self-care: Make sure to take care of your body and mind during this challenging month. Practice self-care activities such as meditation, yoga, or reading to help manage stress and maintain a positive mindset.
